Key Arguments: The draft bill sets unclear and poorly designed standards that may contravene UN Article 19 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
Legal prescriptions on social media content regulation can affect freedom of speech.
The USA's legal challenges to social media content control should be considered before implementing similar laws in Australia.
The draft bill exempts government postings from scrutiny, which could lead to misinformation from the government itself.
The request for more powers came from ACMA, not public demand, indicating a bureaucratic overreach.
The Fact Sheet-Key Points do not align with the actual effects of the draft bill, potentially leading to over-censorship by social media companies.
Notable Quotes: By setting unclear poorly designed standards this draft bill will have an effect of contravening Australia's requirements to comply with UN article 19 Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
The USA Biden administration has recently had the following legal challenge to its attempts to control social media content.
Giving governments this power to post untruths without consequence is the most dangerous aspect of this draft bill.
I will fight for everyone's right to free speech regardless of whether I agree with their ideas or not.
